subject: Art
title: Hand Lettering
description: Custom-drawn letters that bring human warmth and uniqueness.

hook.text: Hand lettering isn't handwriting â€” it's drawing letters. Each letterform is carefully constructed, sketched, refined, and polished. The result: type that feels human, unique, and impossible to replicate with a font.

buildup.text: Process: 1) Sketch rough letter shapes (pencil). 2) Refine proportions and spacing. 3) Ink final forms. 4) Digitize if needed. Tools: brush pens, pointed pens, flat-edged nibs, chalk, or digital brushes.

discovery.text: Hand lettering adds what fonts can't: personality, imperfection, and soul. A hand-lettered cafÃ© sign, book cover, or wedding invitation carries emotional warmth that no typed font can match.

twist.text: Good hand lettering requires understanding typography. You need to know letter proportions, spacing rules, and structural consistency BEFORE breaking them expressively. Freedom comes from knowledge, not ignorance.

climax.text: Letter your name in three styles: formal script (elegant connections), block letters (bold and structured), and casual brush (loose and energetic). Each requires different tools and techniques â€” same letters, completely different vibes.

punchline.text: Hand lettering is where typography meets illustration. Every stroke is both a letter and a brushmark.

quiz.question: How does hand lettering differ from handwriting?
options: Hand lettering is carefully drawn and constructed, while handwriting is spontaneous writing
